_comment: Created by EFisher on 12/10/2015 14:28:52 using v2.7
title: How strongly do seasons influence breaches?
analysis_commentary: The impact of "winter pressures" on A&E performance against the four-hour target has been the subject of some debate. This chart shows weekly performance for major A&E units indexed to the start of the calendar year - so weeks 1 to 4 are January, weeks 5 to 8 are February and so on. There is a general trend for performance to be higher in the summer - despite the fact that A&E sees the highest numbers of attendees at this time. This is explained by changes in the case-mix of people attending. In summer A&E sees a higher proportion of cuts and sprains, most of which can be treated relatively quickly. A large dip in performance can be seen in the first 18 weeks of 2013. Performance trends appear more consistent towards the second-half of the year, although the 2014 data does not achieve a similar level and in fact declines dramatically towards the end of the year. 2015 begins with a particularly low level of performance, with only 80% of patients seen within 4 hours in the first week of the year. Performance does, however, pick up as the year continues, although the performance levels do not match those of 2011, 2012 and 2013.
data_source: NHS England, A&E Waiting Times and Activity
